file_content.text: Your services were greatly appreciated, but I really must get back to work.
If you are who I think you are, then you have done me a great disservice. There is nothing for us to discuss.
Come in. I'm Senator Barc. Heerimus told me he found someone to aid in our cause--I presume that brave citizen is you.
Tell me, did you recover my shipment from the Migrant Merchants' Guild? Those chips are very valuable.
What are you planning to do with these chips?
What is this shipment for?
Captain Denal-zon told me about the chips.
I know the truth.
I assure you, my intentions serve the good of the Republic--regardless of what the captain may have told you.
Laws regulating slavery are holding the Republic back. These chips--innovative, labor-saving and simple to use--can help demonstrate why it's time for a change.
Are you actually trying to legalize slavery?
Change the law how?
Yes. That's exactly what I intend to do.
The current laws are the ones we must obey.
You got the chips illegally.
Progress often requires the sacrifice of outdated ideals.
People aren't going to embrace slavery just because new tech makes it easier.
You'll need more than chips.
All too true. This is only the first step of many.
Slavery was once an accepted practice in the Republic. It continues with great effectiveness on many Outer Rim worlds.
The Sith Empire makes extensive use of slave labor, which is one of many factors that gives the Empire a military and economic advantage.
The Republic was founded on democracy, not slavery.
We cannot lose our ideals.
We mustn't give in to the dark side's temptations.
Might doesn't make right.
I'm not going to debate with you, Jedi. You have no right to impose your order's quaint values on the Republic.
I appreciate your help recovering my stolen property. If you give me my computer chips, you can be on your way.
I didn't enlist to help enslave innocent people, sir.
But we fight for freedom!
Your idealism is refreshing, but we're not fighting for ideals, we're fighting for survival.
I have no time for a lengthy philosophical debate. Can I have my chips now, please?
It always comes down to credits, doesn't it?
"Economic advantage," huh?
Credits buy technology and supplies--the things that determine military strength and superiority.
I don't think so.
You're right.
I'm glad you have the intelligence to grasp this notion. We can only hope that others will eventually come around.
Here's the shipment.
I'm sure Heerimus mentioned generous compensation for your services, in addition to the privilege of serving the Republic.
If you will hand over my shipment now, we can talk about your reward.
These chips should be destroyed.
Not a chance.
You uptight moralist. It's people like you who are holding the Republic back.
I will not give up the fight. I will find a way to return the Republic to its former glory.
The chips are all yours, Senator.
Here you go.
Thank you. Please take this in exchange for your services.
Now, if you will excuse me, I have quite a lot of work to do. But I'm proud to have worked with such a patriot.
If you'll pardon me, I have pressing matters to attend to. I do hope we can talk later.
